Indications and doses

Cycloplegia,

To the eye using eye drop

  • For adults
    (consult product literature).

Anterior uveitis,

To the eye using eye drop

  • For adults
    (consult product literature).

Bradycardia due to acute massive overdosage of beta-blockers,

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    3 mg.
  • For children
    40 micrograms/kg (max. per dose 3 mg).

Treatment of poisoning by organophosphorus insecticide or nerve agent (in combination with pralidoxime chloride),

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    2 mg every 5–10 minutes until the skin becomes flushed and dry, the pupils dilate, and bradycardia is abolished, frequency of administration dependent on the severity of poisoning.
  • For children
    20 micrograms/kg every 5–10 minutes (max. per dose 2 mg) until the skin becomes flushed and dry, the pupils dilate, and bradycardia is abolished, frequency of administration dependent on the severity of poisoning.

Symptomatic relief of gastro-intestinal disorders characterised by smooth muscle spasm,

By mouth

  • For adults
    0.6–1.2 mg daily, dose to be taken at night.

Premedication,

By subcutaneous injection or by intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    300–600 micrograms, to be administered immediately before induction of anaesthesia.
  • For adults
    300–600 micrograms, to be administered 30–60 minutes before induction of anaesthesia.
  • For children 12–17 years
    300–600 micrograms, to be administered immediately before induction of anaesthesia.
  • For children 12–17 years
    300–600 micrograms, to be administered 30–60 minutes before induction of anaesthesia.

Intra-operative bradycardia,

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    300–600 micrograms, larger doses may be used in emergencies.
  • For children 12–17 years
    300–600 micrograms, larger doses may be used in emergencies.

Control of muscarinic side-effects of neostigmine in reversal of competitive neuromuscular block,

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    0.6–1.2 mg.
  • For children 12–17 years
    0.6–1.2 mg.

Excessive bradycardia associated with beta-blocker use,

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    0.6–2.4 mg every hour in divided doses (max. per dose 600 micrograms).

Bradycardia following myocardial infarction (particularly if complicated by hypotension),

By intravenous injection

  • For adults
    500 micrograms every 3–5 minutes; maximum 3 mg.

Advice when patient is pregnant

With systemic use

Not known to be harmful; manufacturer advises caution.

Known side effects

When used by eye in children

Toxic systemic reactions can occur in neonates and children.

When used by eye

Systemic side-effects can occur, particularly in children and the elderly.

Directions for administration

With oral use in children

For administration by mouth, injection solution may be given orally.

Important safety information

Antimuscarininc drugs used for premedication to general anaesthesia should only be administered by, or under the direct supervision of, personnel experienced in their use.

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

With intravenous use

Control of muscarinic side-effects of neostigmine in reversal of competitive neuromuscular block

Since atropine has a shorter duration of action than neostigmine, late unopposed bradycardia may result; close monitoring of the patient is necessary.

Unlicensed use

When used by eye in children

Not licensed for use in children for uveitis.

With systemic use in children

Not licensed for use by oral route.

Not licensed for use in children under 12 years for intra-operative bradycardia or by intravenous route for premedication.

Not licensed for the control of muscarinic side-effects of edrophonium in reversal of competitive neuromuscular block.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

When used by eye

Although multi-dose atropine sulphate eye drops commonly contain preservatives, preservative-free unit dose vials may be available.

Conditions when less suitable for prescribing

With oral use in adults

Atropine tablets less suitable for prescribing. Any clinical benefit as a gastro-intestinal antispasmodic is outweighed by atropinic side-effects.

Exceptions to legal category

With intramuscular use or intravenous use or subcutaneous use

Prescription only medicine restriction does not apply where administration is for saving life in emergency.

Prepared medicinal forms of ATROPINE SULFATE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: eye drops, solution for injection, oral suspension, solution for infusion, oral solution, eye ointment,
